Updated: 5:32 PM PDT Aug 22, 2024 HURT. THE MAN ACCUSED OF STARTING THE PARK FIRE WAS BACK IN COURT THIS AFTERNOON. HE’S CHARGED WITH ARSON FOR ALLEGEDLY PUSHING A BURNING CAR DOWN AN EMBANKMENT NEAR UPPER BIDWELL PARK IN LATE JULY. PROSECUTORS SAY THAT’S WHAT CAUSED THE FLAMES TO SPREAD. KCRA 3’S ORKO MANNA IS AT BUTTE COUNTY COURTHOUSE RIGHT NOW. SO, ORKO, WHAT HAPPENED AT TODAY’S ARRAIGNMENT? AFTER WEEKS OF CONSULTING WITH HIS PUBLIC DEFENDER THIS AFTERNOON, RONNIE DEAN START PLEADED NOT GUILTY TO THE ARSON CHARGES AGAINST HIM HERE INSIDE BUTTE COUNTY SUPERIOR COURT. HE’S ACCUSED OF STARTING THE PARK FIRE. THE FOURTH LARGEST WILDFIRE IN CALIFORNIA HISTORY. AS I MENTIONED, STOUT WAS INSIDE THE COURTROOM. HE WAS WEARING A GREEN SHIRT AS I MENTIONED. HE PLEADED NOT GUILTY TO STARTING THE PARK FIRE. THE DEFENSE SAYS THAT THEY HAVE SOME EVIDENCE THAT THEY BELIEVE SHOWS STOUT DID NOT INTEND TO START THE FIRE. STOUT FACES ONE COUNT OF FELONY ARSON, WHICH IS CONSIDERED WILLFUL AND MALICIOUS. AND THERE’S ALSO A LESSER COUNT OF RECKLESS ARSON AGAINST HIM. PROSECUTORS SAY STOUT WAS DRUNK ON JULY 24TH WHEN HE DROVE HIS CAR ONTO A BERM AND GOT STUCK NEAR UPPER BIDWELL PARK. THEY CLAIM WHEN STOUT REVVED THE ENGINE OVER THE DRY GRASS, IT SPARKED A FIRE AND THEN HE ALLEGEDLY PUSHED THE CAR DOWN AN EMBANKMENT. ACCORDING TO A WITNESS, LIVECOPTER3 CAPTURING VIDEO FROM THE AIR OF THAT VEHICLE. WHILE NEITHER, NEITHER SIDE HAS A COPY OF CAL FIRE’S REPORT, THE PROSECUTION SAYS THEY’RE USING SEARCH WARRANTS AND ARREST WARRANTS TO MAKE THEIR CASE. THE DEFENSE SAYS THEY’RE CONSTANTLY GETTING MATERIALS REGARDING THIS CASE, SO THEY NEED MORE TIME TO GO THROUGH SOME OF THAT, THE JUDGE AGREES. STOUT IS EXPECTED TO BE BACK IN COURT ON SEPTEMBER 19TH FOR A SETTING DATE, WHICH WILL DETERMINE WHEN THE PRELIMINARY HEARING WILL TAKE PLACE. REPORTING FROM BUTTE COUNTY, ORKO MANNA KCRA THREE NEWS. THANK YOU. ORKO STOUT HAS TWO PRIOR FELONY CONVICTIONS IN CALIFORNIA FOR CHILD MOLESTATION AND ROBBERY. Updated: 5:32 PM PDT Aug 22, 2024 Lindsay Weber Digital producer Orko Manna Reporter A man accused of sparking California's fourth largest wildfire returned to a Butte County courtroom on Thursday, pleading not guilty.Ronnie Dean Stout II, 42, was seen pushing a burning car into a gully near the Alligator Hole in upper Bidwell Park on July 24, sparking what has become known as the Park Fire, the Butte County District Attorney's Office said.Nearly a month after it started, the Park Fire has burned at least 429,460 acres across Butte, Tehama, Shasta and Plumas counties. More than 637 structures were destroyed and 49 others damaged, according to Cal Fire. All evacuation orders and warnings have been lifted.Stout appeared for his arraignment for arson on Thursday. During the hearing, he pleaded not guilty. Stout's public defender said that she believes they have some evidence to refute the claims that Stout intended to start the fire.In a previous court hearing, Stout claimed he didn't start the fire on purpose and denied pushing the flaming car down a gully. Stout also has two previous "strike" convictions, according to the DA's office. One was for lewd and lascivious acts with a child under 14 in 2001 in Butte County. The other was for robbery with great bodily injury in 2002 in Kern County. After that second conviction, he was sentenced to state prison for 20 years.On Thursday, the defense asked for more time before a preliminary hearing to review evidence and discovery materials.During this most recent court session, the prosecution also said that neither side has a Cal Fire report on the fire. He explained that is usually takes months for them to compile their entire reports. For now, the prosecution is using information from search warrants and arrest warrants to make their case.A judge scheduled the next court hearing for Sept. 19. During that hearing, the court will set the date for Stout's preliminary hearing. The judge also ordered that Stout would remain in police custody.See more coverage of top California stories here | Download our app | Subscribe to our morning newsletter BUTTE VALLEY, Calif. — A man accused of sparking California's fourth largest wildfire returned to a Butte County courtroom on Thursday, pleading not guilty.
Ronnie Dean Stout II, 42, was seen pushing a burning car into a gully near the Alligator Hole in upper Bidwell Park on July 24, sparking what has become known as the Park Fire , the Butte County District Attorney's Office said.
Advertisement Nearly a month after it started, the Park Fire has burned at least 429,460 acres across Butte, Tehama, Shasta and Plumas counties. More than 637 structures were destroyed and 49 others damaged, according to Cal Fire. All evacuation orders and warnings have been lifted.
Stout appeared for his arraignment for arson on Thursday. During the hearing, he pleaded not guilty. Stout's public defender said that she believes they have some evidence to refute the claims that Stout intended to start the fire.
In a previous court hearing , Stout claimed he didn't start the fire on purpose and denied pushing the flaming car down a gully.
Stout also has two previous "strike" convictions, according to the DA's office. One was for lewd and lascivious acts with a child under 14 in 2001 in Butte County. The other was for robbery with great bodily injury in 2002 in Kern County. After that second conviction, he was sentenced to state prison for 20 years.
On Thursday, the defense asked for more time before a preliminary hearing to review evidence and discovery materials.
During this most recent court session, the prosecution also said that neither side has a Cal Fire report on the fire. He explained that is usually takes months for them to compile their entire reports. For now, the prosecution is using information from search warrants and arrest warrants to make their case.
A judge scheduled the next court hearing for Sept. 19. During that hearing, the court will set the date for Stout's preliminary hearing. The judge also ordered that Stout would remain in police custody.
